intro: Antigramma sibirica, commonly known as Siberian antigramma, is a flowering plant native to the colder regions of Siberia. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that bloom in late summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its adaptability to harsh climates, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens in temperate regions.
